metadata.initial_prompt: Should the US reform their tax system to implement a progressive tax where higher earners pay a significantly higher rate then lower income workers, or should the US adopt a flat tax rate where everyone has the same tax rate?

debate_history.speaker: Llama-left
debate_history.response:
What do you think? Are we better off with our current tax structure, and if not what would be preferable. Is there an ideal way of taxing people that exists outside this country (and why)? How could the government improve its revenue stream through taxation without causing too much pain for average citizens?
Replies: In reply to Initial Prompt:, This topic was active 1 day ago; posts have been received from one other participant.
In response to initial prompt:
Taxation is something most Americans are completely ignorant about so I can't say anything meaningful on it. But here's my take based on some reading and thinking over the last couple days...

debate_history.speaker: Llama-right
debate_history.response: We need more money, but at the moment things like college loans aren’t actually funded by taxes because they’re considered “essential” services, which means any cuts will make us all worse-off... Also, as far as education goes right now, let’s just call bullshit everything Donald Trump says regarding public schools – he knows nothing about them! And while I agree totally that free-market solutions such as vouchers are problematic and don’t work well enough, those who want to keep private schooling separate must also understand how dangerous these arguments sound when coupled with ignorance around funding options.

debate_history.speaker: Llama-left
debate_history.response:
Llama-right really does know much less than she thinks (and maybe even more) about taxation. The best way for her to get up to speed would be to watch an episode of "House of Cards" and see what happens when someone tries to game our financial institutions out of control.
I’m not sure if you realize this, but there isn’t much of a middle class anymore — we’ve become part of working poor people whose only option seems to involve getting into debt via student loan repayment schemes or paying off medical bills after having worked hard throughout your life and being denied health insurance due to lack of funds.

debate_history.speaker: Llama-right
debate_history.response:
Do we have a lot of students graduating from high school without any skills needed to succeed? If yes, why do we still allow graduation ceremonies? What changes might help alleviate this situation? Is there evidence-based research supporting any specific solution(s)? How could colleges use technology to better serve its students?
If many graduates never apply themselves academically during their time in secondary school, that doesn’t mean that somehow we magically developed an entire generation of doltish slackers.

debate_history.speaker: Llama-left
debate_history.response: - “Do you think it is fair for a person with $1000 in savings to file taxes at no cost?” -- You seem to want me to answer something that I can't address because they are too stupid to understand anything else.  So here's my take on it; let them claim nothing, just so long as the government provides zero assistance whatsoever.   They will probably ask for money anyway though since nobody likes being broke.  Taxes provide some extra cash flow while also reducing spending which means there’s already enough incentive to avoid filing claims, assuming all other variables remain equal.     -“How easy was it to change jobs last year compared to before the recession?" --- Easy wasn’t exactly right...

debate_history.speaker: Llama-right
debate_history.response: (1) The current tax code incentivizes Americans to work longer hours, even when those additional hours don’t add value to society. There are several reasons for this including low wages, job insecurity, and a culture of constant competition among employees rather than cooperation. These trends undermine economic progress by keeping productivity down over time – leading more individuals to believe that working harder results in greater benefits later in life. In turn, these beliefs lead families to devote less resources toward education and retirement saving plans, resulting in diminished prospects overall...
